Introduction to MATLAB

History

MATLAB started out as a simple matrix calculator instead of a programming language. Cleve Moler, the creator of MATLAB and the founder of MathWorks, is a mathematician who specializes in numerical analysis. In the 1970s, when he was teaching at the University of New Mexico, he wanted his students to have easy access to numerical computing libraries without having to use the Fortran programming language. He wrote the first version of MATLAB--short for Matrix Laboratory--as an interactive matrix calculator in the Fortran language.

In 1983, Jack Little, a graduate student at Stanford, suggested that Moler commercialize MATLAB. Little wrote a new and extended version of MATLAB using C, for the newly introduced IBM PC computers. This version of MATLAB contained functions, toolboxes, and graphics. PC-MATLAB debuted in 1984, with versions for other computers debuting soon after. Modern MATLAB has kept its roots in matrix mathematics while evolving to meet the needs of engineers and scientists. Today, over 4 million people use MATLAB worldwide!

Wellesley-Specific Information

ENGR 160, Fundamentals of Engineering, is currently the only Wellesley course that uses this language (prior to 2020, CS112 used to focus on MATLAB, but the new 2025 version of CS112 will use Python).

However, some tools in MATLAB have been incorporated into more commonly used languages, such as Python, in the form of libraries (ex: matplotlib). Therefore, it is useful to learn MATLAB no matter what language you may be coding in. You may also find MATLAB to be useful for scientific courses such as Computational Biology.

Best IDEs

MATLAB has its own IDE, therefore that is the best IDE to use. However, some third-party IDEs do support MATLAB, and you can find more information regarding them here.

Applications

According to MathWorks, MATLAB is best used for scientific or engineering applications such as data analysis and visualization, signal and image processing, control systems, wireless communications, computational finance, computational biology, and robotics. MATLAB is mainly used for numeric computing, with tools that allow for graphics, simulations, and model-based designs. To learn more about MATLAB versus general-purpose programming languages, click here.

Photo via MathWorks.

Further Resources

The MathWorks website has extensive documentation regarding MATLAB. MathWorks hosts MATLAB Central, a community for publishing information about MATLAB. It includes a Q&A page, a code-sharing hub, file exchanges, a blog, and much more. If you want to learn the basics of MATLAB, MathWorks provides self-paced classes on MATLAB Onramp.

Citations

Moler, Cleve. “A Brief History of MATLAB.” MathWorks. https://www.mathworks.com/company/newsletters/articles/a-brief-history-of-matlab.html."
